results.title: Rome and Pompeii
results.brief_description: The magnificence or Rome and Pompeii as they were about 2,000 years ago is reconstructed before your eyes. See the Colosseum, as it stood, with 50,000 Romans applauding the bloody gladiator spectacles. Walk the Roman Forum in all its splendour. See the Circus Maximus where 150,000 cheered the chariot races. Gaze at the lavish lifestyles in both Rome and Pompeii - the baths, theatres, temples, palaces and shopping markets. Watch Neros Rome ablaze and Mount Vesuvius devastation of Pompeii, recreated as it might have happened.

results.title: Romanticism: revolt of the spirit
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Columbia Pictures, John H. Secondari and Helen Jean Secondari
results.brief_description: Shelley’s death and funeral epitomises the individualistic and emotional spirit of the Romantic Age and serves as a focus for this film. The writers of the age were turning away from the conventional, established themes of literature. They wrote personal, simple subjects, as the dramatisation of Wordsworth’s ‘Solitary Reaper’ and Hood’s ‘Seamstress’ reveals. The Romantic artist dealt directly with his emotional responses - Victor Hugo’s indignation at the injustices of society is shown in a scene from Les Miserables; Shelley’s pity and compassion for his fellow men emerges in his ‘Son to the Men of England’. The death scene from Wuthering Heights shows the passionate response to love and death that charactised the era. Includes extracts from Wordsworth, Shelley, Victor Hugo and Emily Bronte.

results.title: Romantic England. No. 9 [Edward V, 1483]
results.brief_description: Historical documentary about King Edward V and his ruthless and cunning uncle, Richard, Duke of Gloucester, who plotted and schemed to depose the young Edward from the throne. It tells of the two princes, Edward and his younger brother Richard, and how their uncle sent them to imprisonment and their eventual death in the Tower, naming himself as the rightful heir to the crown. Commentary written by Horace Shepherd and spoken by Neal Arden.

results.creator_credit: Castle Films and United World Films

results.title: Romantic
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Orchestra Series”.
Part Four of the Orchestra series which describes the evolution of the modern symphony orchestra from its beginnings in the 17th century to the present. The centre-piece of this program is composer, innovator and orchestrator, Hector Berlioz. Jane Glover conducts the London Philharmonic Orchestra playing excerpts from Berlioz’s “Treatise on Orchestration”. The Romantic Movement, with its emphasis on “man’s free will”, brought about a radical shift in the composer’s use of the orchestra, changing its role to that of storyteller.

results.title: Romania
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: Romania, for centuries an agricultural country whose people were mostly herdsmen, is now one of Eastern Europe’s most rapidly developing industrial nations. Surveys the country, its people geography and industry, and illustrates the changes taking place as the society progresses from rural to urban-industrial.

results.title: Romance and reality; Man the measure of all things
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, Michael Gill, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 3 and 4 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 3: “Romance and reality” - Sir Kenneth journeys from a castle in the Loire, through the hill towns of Tuscany and Umbria to the cathedral baptistery at Pisa as he explores the aspirations and achievements of the later Middle Ages in France and Italy. Part 4. “Man the Measure of all Things” - Sir Kenneth visits Florence where European thought was first given a new impetus by the rediscovery of the classical past. He then continues his journey to the palaces of Urbino and Mantua, centres of Renaissance civilisation.

results.title: Roman fact, Roman fable
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The first installment of the Roman’s in Britain Series discusses the history of Britain in relation to the Roman invasion and occupation of its shores over a number of centuries. The program explores the tribal groups that previously occupied the area and the systematic take over that the Romans succeeded in achieving in AD43 and the subsequent impact this had on the cultural and societal life of the previous inhabitants. Through thorough narration, interviews with historians and archaeologists, reenactments, reconstructions of archaeological findings and excerpts from film and television depictions of this historical period the various myths, facts and speculations about this time in history are explored and analysed with a view to creating an accurate perspective on the classical past in Britain and the Roman impact on the country that is still visible today.

group_siblings.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire

results.title: Roman coins = Moneta Romana
results.brief_description: Shows Roman coins produced during the 5th century BC and succeeding centuries, depicting the grandeur and fall of Rome and the qualities of its emperors and leaders. The coins show that money was needed everywhere to build colosseums, for state funerals and for negotiations with Africa, Spain and Gallia. It was the Senate that decided to replace the small bronze coins with silver ones. Commentary in Italian.

results.title: Roman art and architecture
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hearst and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Grandeur that Was Rome”.
A discussion of ancient Rome’s art and architecture, particularly of functional constructions such as aqueducts, and of domes and large interiors.
